Situation1: Going to the gym to maintain physical fitness
Situation2: Medical advice suggests this may be their final opportunity to travel long distances.
Story: I laced up my sneakers, ready for another early morning at the gym. As a police officer, staying fit isn’t just a personal goal—it’s a duty. My captain always says, “You can’t protect others if you can’t protect yourself.” I take that seriously. Every rep, every mile, is for the people I serve. But lately, my mind drifts elsewhere. My doctor’s words echo in my head: “If you want to perform Hajj, you should go soon. Your health may not allow it later.” As a Muslim, Hajj is a pillar of my faith, a once-in-a-lifetime obligation. My family urges me to go, reminding me of the spiritual fulfillment and the peace it brings. Yet, the department is short-staffed, and my absence would leave my team vulnerable. I feel torn—my badge weighs heavy on one side, my faith on the other. The treadmill hums beneath me, but my thoughts race faster, caught between duty to my community and duty to my Creator.
